snippet: Aetna Inc., one of the nation's biggest health insurers, said yesterday that its U.S. Healthcare health plans would eliminate coverage for advanced fertility treatments, including in vitro fertilization, on April 1.     The company said that women...
lead_paragraph: Aetna Inc., one of the nation's biggest health insurers, said yesterday that its U.S. Healthcare health plans would eliminate coverage for advanced fertility treatments, including in vitro fertilization, on April 1. The company said that women who had fertility problems had been joining the U.S. Healthcare plans because they knew the advanced treatments were available. Aetna has recently been under pressure from Wall Street investors to reduce costs and increase profits.
abstract: US Healthcare unit of Aetna Inc will eliminate coverage for advanced fertility treatments, including in vitro fertilization; says women were joining its plans because they knew the advanced treatments were available; Aetna has been under pressure from Wall Street investors to reduce costs and increase profits; decision is criticized by doctors and advocates of infertility patients, who say many couples are already struggling to cover costs of such treatments out of their own pockets; photo (M)

headline.main: AETNA IS REDUCING FERTILITY BENEFITS

headline.main: Where More Women Are on Boards, Executive Pay Is Higher
headline.print_headline: Boards With More Women Grant Higher Pay

snippet: Dr. Barbara A. DeBuono said yesterday that she would step down as the New York State Commissioner of Health, a position she has held for nearly four years in a time of great change in the state's health care system.    Dr. DeBuono, 43, will become...
lead_paragraph: Dr. Barbara A. DeBuono said yesterday that she would step down as the New York State Commissioner of Health, a position she has held for nearly four years in a time of great change in the state's health care system. Dr. DeBuono, 43, will become what amounts to the No. 3 executive at New York Presbyterian Healthcare System, the new conglomeration of 28 hospitals, nursing homes and other health care agencies assembled around one of the nation's most prestigious medical institutions, the New York and Presbyterian Hospital.
abstract: Dr Barbara A DeBuono says she will step down as New York State Commissioner of Health, position she has held for nearly four years in time of great change in state's health care system; DeBuono will become what amounts to No 3 executive at New York Presbyterian Healthcare System, new conglomeration of 28 hospitals, nursing homes and other health care agencies assembled around one of nation's most prestigious medical institutions, New York and Presbyterian Hospital; she will begin her new job on Nov 1 (M)

headline.main: Health Commissioner Is Leaving

snippet: State health officials and the local police are investigating accusations that patients undergoing psychiatric or substance-abuse treatment at St. Vincent's Westchester Hospital in Harrison have been sexually abused or beaten by other patients, of...
lead_paragraph: State health officials and the local police are investigating accusations that patients undergoing psychiatric or substance-abuse treatment at St. Vincent's Westchester Hospital in Harrison have been sexually abused or beaten by other patients, officials said on Friday. The police in Harrison said on Friday that on Wednesday they arrested a former patient, a girl under age 16, on charges of sexual assault and aggravated sexual assault at the hospital late last year.
abstract: State and local authorities investigate accusations that patients undergoing psychiatric or substance-abuse treatment at St Vincent's Westchester Hospital in Harrison, NY, were sexually and physical abused by other patients; some victims or their abusers have been under age 16; police have investigated 27 reports of abuse at hospital since 1997, and there have been two convictions; hospital says attorneys involved in lawsuits are distorting facts; photo (M)

headline.main: Patient-Abuse Charges Under Investigation

snippet: Depression may be described as feeling sad, blue, unhappy, miserable, or down in the dumps. Most of us feel this way at one time or another for short periods. Clinical depression is a mood disorder in which feelings of sadness, loss, anger, or fru...
lead_paragraph: Depression may be described as feeling sad, blue, unhappy, miserable, or down in the dumps. Most of us feel this way at one time or another for short periods. Clinical depression is a mood disorder in which feelings of sadness, loss, anger, or frustration interfere with everyday life for a longer period of time. For more information on the symptoms and treatment of depression, see: Adolescent depression Bipolar disorder Depression in the elderly Dysthymia Major depression

headline.main: Depression

True clinical depression is an illness. It is a mood disorder in which feelings of sadness, loss, anger, or frustration interfere with daily life for weeks or longer.

headline.main: Major Depression

snippet: A nonprofit group that evaluates 15,000 health-care organizations nationwide has removed Greystone Park State Psychiatric Hospital from an ''accreditation watch'' that had jeopardized the center, officials said.    The Joint Commission on Accredit...
lead_paragraph: A nonprofit group that evaluates 15,000 health-care organizations nationwide has removed Greystone Park State Psychiatric Hospital from an ''accreditation watch'' that had jeopardized the center, officials said. The Joint Commission on Accreditation of Healthcare Organizations had put the hospital on notice after the suicides of three patients and the choking death of a fourth, all of which occurred during a 13-month period ending last year.
abstract: Joint Commission on Accreditation of Healthcare Organizations removes Greystone Park State Psychiatric Hospital in New Jersey from an 'accreditation watch' that had jeopardized center (S)

headline.main: Greystone Accreditation No Longer in Jeopardy

snippet: CONSUMERS may be wondering what happened to the Today Sponge, which has disappeared from drugstores nationally. Thousands of users of the sponge, a popular over-the-counter female contraceptive, have been searching for it since early last summer. ...
lead_paragraph: CONSUMERS may be wondering what happened to the Today Sponge, which has disappeared from drugstores nationally. Thousands of users of the sponge, a popular over-the-counter female contraceptive, have been searching for it since early last summer. Whitehall-Robins Healthcare, a division of the American Home Products Corporation, which manufactures the sponge in Hammonton, N.J., voluntarily halted production more than a year ago after a routine Food and Drug Administration inspection found a problem in the plant's water purification system.

headline.main: What Happened to Today Sponge

abstract: Some financially strong Catholic-sponsored medical centers are increasingly joining with small secular hospitals, in some cases limiting access to treatments like contraception, abortion and sterilization; this trend in health care economics is magnifying the tension as Roman Catholic leaders and government officials clash over the proper role of religion and reproductive health.

snippet: A total cholesterol test measures all the cholesterol in your blood. Cholesterol is a soft, wax-like substance found in all parts of the body. Your body needs a little bit of cholesterol to work properly. But too much cholesterol can clog your art...
lead_paragraph: A total cholesterol test measures all the cholesterol in your blood. Cholesterol is a soft, wax-like substance found in all parts of the body. Your body needs a little bit of cholesterol to work properly. But too much cholesterol can clog your arteries and lead to heart disease. Some cholesterol is considered "good" and some is considered "bad." Different blood tests are needed to individually measure each type of cholesterol. See also: HDL test (high density lipoprotein, or "good" cholesterol) High blood cholesterol and triglycerides LDL test (low density lipoprotein, or "bad" cholesterol) Lipid profile

headline.main: Cholesterol Test

snippet: Health care.. for. women, long one of the major issues of the-women's movement, was discussed and dissected here at a day-long conference that turned out-to be more of a gripe session than anything else. Called "Psychological Perspectives in Women...
lead_paragraph: Health care.. for. women, long one of the major issues of the-women's movement, was discussed and dissected here at a day-long conference that turned out-to be more of a gripe session than anything else. Called "Psychological Perspectives in Women's Medicine: - Telling- It the Way It Feels," it was a get-together to discuss such things as unnecessary surgery, ondescension of doctors to women patients, depression as a feminist issue, and medical consumerism.
abstract: Consultation Center for Women and Eastern Women's Center, NYC, co-sponsor symposium called Psychological Perspectives in Women's Med: Telling It the Way It Feels; conf is discussion of women's reactions to health care they receive; features guest panel of psychologists, gynecologists, science writers, natural health experts and a nurse-midwife; author Barbara Seaman, clinical psychologist Freyda Zell and Dr Edward Stim comment; illus (M)

headline.main: Women and Their Doctors--The Sad and Cautionary Tales; Describes Hostility

snippet: To the growing numbers of medical experts who preach evidence-based medicine -- the discipline that insists on proof that time-honored medical practices and procedures are actually effective -- there is no more inviting target than the annual phys...
lead_paragraph: To the growing numbers of medical experts who preach evidence-based medicine -- the discipline that insists on proof that time-honored medical practices and procedures are actually effective -- there is no more inviting target than the annual physical. Checkups for people with no medical complaint remain the single most common reason for visiting a doctor, according to surveys by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. In 2000, they accounted for about 64 million office visits, out of 823.5 million visits over all. At $120 to $150 per visit (and $2,000 or so for the gold-plated ''executive physical'' that many companies offer to top executives), that adds up to more than $7 billion a year.
abstract: Annual medical checkups remain most common reason people visit their doctor, despite series of reports beginning in 1989 that find little support for symptomless physicals; committee sponsored by federal Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality finds routine physicals can lead to false alarms and unnecessary, and sometimes risky, follow-up tests; doctors admit they continue to do annual physicals for variety of reasons, including routine familiarity and simply keeping their patients happy, but they themselves question tangible benefit in yearly ritual; annual checkup does help establish doctor-patient relationship, giving people sense of confidence they have someone to help if symptoms do arise; story of Dr John K Min exemplifies dilemma doctors face; photos (M)

headline.main: Annual Physical Checkup May Be an Empty Ritual

snippet: New York and New Jersey will automatically quarantine medical workers returning from Ebola-hit West African countries and the U.S. government is considering the same step after a doctor who treated patients in Guinea came back infected, officials ...
lead_paragraph: New York and New Jersey will automatically quarantine medical workers returning from Ebola-hit West African countries and the U.S. government is considering the same step after a doctor who treated patients in Guinea came back infected, officials said on Friday.

snippet: The New York State Catholic Conference produced a blistering 9-minute YouTube video that assails a proposal by the Spitzer administration to revise the state abortion law....
lead_paragraph: The New York State Catholic Conference has produced a blistering nine-minute YouTube video that assails a proposal by the Spitzer administration to update abortion laws. The creation of the video, which argues that the State Senate offers the best hope of defeating the measure, suggests that abortion could emerge as a hot issue in the state elections this fall. Republicans will try to hold on to their thin margin in the Senate, their last bastion of power in Albany, but strong turnout for the presidential election could aid Democratic efforts to take control of the entire Legislature for the first time in decades.
abstract: The New York State Catholic Conference produced a blistering 9-minute YouTube video that assails a proposal by the Spitzer administration to revise the state abortion law.

headline.main: Video Intensifies Abortion Debate in Albany

snippet: Women's place in professional schools: more is merrier....
lead_paragraph: Lena Kagan, the first female dean of Harvard Law School, had an epiphany in the women's bathroom at a conference hall in Cambridge, Mass., last year. There, neatly stacked in a basket, was a supply of free tampons. ''It's such a small thing, but it says a lot about whether a place cares about its women,'' she says. A few months later, every women's room at Harvard Law had a supply. Change is taking many forms these days at the nation's professional schools. Business students network at potluck dinners. Medical schools incorporate more materials on women's health. At law schools, the Socratic method has come under attack, its dominance diluted by approaches thought to be more woman-friendly. The changes reflect the schools' responses to increased numbers of female students.
abstract: Yilu Zhao article on how nation's law, business and medical schools are changing in ways that reflect increased numbers of female students; photo (special section, Education Life) (L)

headline.main: Beyond 'Sweetie'

snippet: The Hartford nursing home where 10 residents died in a fire yesterday morning caters to more than just the elderly, having filled its wards in recent years in part by admitting relatively younger people who have schizophrenia, AIDS and other illne...
lead_paragraph: The Hartford nursing home where 10 residents died in a fire yesterday morning caters to more than just the elderly, having filled its wards in recent years in part by admitting relatively younger people who have schizophrenia, AIDS and other illnesses. The population at the 150-bed home, Greenwood Health Center, reflects a growing willingness of nursing home owners across the nation to cast a wider net for residents in order to confront tough fiscal times and new competition.

headline.main: Residents, Increasingly, Are Younger And Troubled
headline.kicker: FATAL NURSING HOME FIRE: THE HOME

headline.main: Slugging It Out With a Reader

snippet: IT took Carla and Bruce P. three and a half gut-wrenching years of invasive medical treatments and more than $40,000 of their savings before Carla got pregnant in April. That makes them part of a small but growing population that beat what the New...
lead_paragraph: IT took Carla and Bruce P. three and a half gut-wrenching years of invasive medical treatments and more than $40,000 of their savings before Carla got pregnant in April. That makes them part of a small but growing population that beat what the New York State Task Force on Life and the Law recognizes as the ''disease'' of infertility. Lucky? Indisputably. First because Carla, a legal assistant, and Bruce, a real-estate broker, succeeded when the biological odds are stacked against a 41-year-old woman conceiving even with high-tech intervention. Second because Carla's new insurance carrier, U.S. Healthcare, paid for the successful round of blood tests, sonograms, laboratory work, egg harvesting, in-vitro fertilization and implanting the resulting embryos. All this was performed by one of New York City's top reproductive medical teams, which was led by Dr. Cecilia Schmidt-Sarosi and her husband, Dr. Peter Sarosi, reproductive endocrinologists.
abstract: Infertility treatment is an expensive proposition, and health coverage tends to be ephemeral, with companies changing policy with lightning speed; new trend in assisted-reproduction is for private infertility centers that operate without the high overhead of a hospital; photo (Special Section: Women's Health) (M)

headline.main: For Infertility Treatments, Now You're Covered, Now You're Not

snippet: The nation is currently engulfed in a huge nursing shortage, which is going to get worse. The baby boomers are long since inured to the idea that when they retire, nobody is going to want to give them Social Security. But they may not have been in...
lead_paragraph: The nation is currently engulfed in a huge nursing shortage, which is going to get worse. The baby boomers are long since inured to the idea that when they retire, nobody is going to want to give them Social Security. But they may not have been informed that when they get old and go into a hospital, there will probably not be anybody on the ward who's authorized to dole out medication. ''We're projecting a 400,000-nurse shortage in 20 years,'' said Douglas Staiger, an economics professor at Dartmouth who is co-author of a series of much-quoted articles on the future of nursing.
abstract: Gail Collins Op-Ed column on severe nursing shortage in United States that is expected to get worse; cites estimate of 400,000-nurse shortage in 20 years, made by Douglas Staiger, economics professor; says women now have more career options and are choosing other professions; says shortage will continue until health management makes nursing more attractive by raising salaries, which now average between $40,000 and $45,000, and improving working conditions (M)

headline.main: Public Interests; Nursing a Shortage

snippet: A 23-year-old woman with a history of emotional problems and drug abuse is the primary suspect in the fast-moving fire at a nursing home here, police officials said today. The fire, which killed 10 frail patients and injured 23 other people early ...
lead_paragraph: A 23-year-old woman with a history of emotional problems and drug abuse is the primary suspect in the fast-moving fire at a nursing home here, police officials said today. The fire, which killed 10 frail patients and injured 23 other people early Wednesday, has raised troubling questions about the operation and safety of such homes. The woman at the center of the investigation was identified by various officials and local news reports as Lesley Andino of Hartford, a mother of two young children who was believed to have entered the home, the Greenwood Health Center, less than a month ago for an indefinite stay.
abstract: Lesley Andino, who has history of emotional problems and drug abuse, is primary suspect in Hartford nursing home fire that killed 10 patients and injured 23 others; is believed to have entered Greenwood Health Center less than one month ago; and has cooperated in interviews with police; fire officials have not determined cause of fire and whether criminal charges will be made; lawmakers wonder whether nursing homes, by taking in younger and more troubled clients, have exposed other patients to unanticipated dangers (M)

headline.main: Suspect in Hartford Fire Is a Troubled Patient

abstract: WakeMed Health and Hospitals in Raleigh, NC, has rolled out pilot program for aiding mentally ill patients without admitting them to emergency rooms, drawing attention of troubled hospitals nationwide; cost of emergency room care for the mentally ill, which is often wasteful and unhelpful, is expected to balloon to $38.5 billion in 2014, even as other health care costs decline.

snippet: A NEW KIND of medical center -- where comprehensive care is provided to women, mostly    by    women -- is gaining popularity in Connecticut. One such center operates in Cheshire; another opened this fall in Groton, and a third is scheduled to sta...
lead_paragraph: A NEW KIND of medical center -- where comprehensive care is provided to women, mostly by women -- is gaining popularity in Connecticut. One such center operates in Cheshire; another opened this fall in Groton, and a third is scheduled to start next year in Vernon. "I think it's a coming trend," said Dr. Carolyn D'Avanzo, a professor of nursing at the University of Connecticut in Storrs. "It's giving women what they want, and it's meeting their needs."

headline.main: Patients Trust Woman-to-Woman Care

snippet: Most American families can thank the woman of the house for nearly all of the pay gains they have received over the last year.    While men's wages have failed to keep up with even the low rate of inflation, women's earnings have continued to grow...
lead_paragraph: Most American families can thank the woman of the house for nearly all of the pay gains they have received over the last year. While men's wages have failed to keep up with even the low rate of inflation, women's earnings have continued to grow, giving an important lift to many families and helping sustain consumer spending.
abstract: Women's earnings have continued to grow over last year, giving important lift to many families, helping to sustain consumer spending and closing gap between men's and women's wages to narrowest on record; men's wages have failed to keep up with even low rate of inflation; women's pay still lags behind men's in every sector of economy; Bureau of Labor Statistics shows women made 77.5 percent of what men did last year; median full-time female worker received 5 percent raise last year, while median pay for men rose only 1.3 percent; pay gap in US is slightly larger than in most other leading economies according to Organization for Economic Cooperation; photo; graph compares wage gender gap (L)

headline.main: Gap Between Pay Of Men and Women Smallest on Record

lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, I wrote about a new technological system that might help hospitals to accurately track whether health care workers are washing their hands, and remind them to do so in real time. The reason hospitals might want to spend the money to install such an expensive fix is that so far, very few hospitals have been able to get their hand-washing rates above 50 percent.

abstract: Panel of health experts assembled by Food and Drug Administration in open forum to discuss contraceptive device Essure, manufactured by Bayer HealthCare Pharmaceuticals, openly criticize both manufacturer and FDA; panel members and women in audience score Bayer for not collecting data they contend could have forecast risks involved with the device; thousands of women allege that device has caused severe pain, perforations of fallopian tubes and possibly even death.

headline.main: F.D.A. Panel Weighs Complaints on Essure Contraceptive Implant
headline.print_headline: Critics of Contraceptive Device Get Public Forum

snippet: Efforts to create a new generation of contraceptive devices are being stymied by lawsuits, the lengthy Government approval process and fears on the part of both consumers and pharmaceutical companies, according to interviews with family planning e...
lead_paragraph: Efforts to create a new generation of contraceptive devices are being stymied by lawsuits, the lengthy Government approval process and fears on the part of both consumers and pharmaceutical companies, according to interviews with family planning experts and a new report by a group that studies reproductive health. As a result, public health officials and other experts in the field said in interviews, it will be many years before any genuinely new methods of contraception become available in this country, despite years of contraceptive research and many promising new approaches.

headline.main: Fears, Suits and Regulations Stall Contraceptive Advances

snippet: Several states are considering imposing tight restrictions on common cold medicines that contain an essential ingredient in making methamphetamine....
lead_paragraph: Faced with a growing crisis of methamphetamine addiction and toxic spills from homemade drug laboratories, 20 states are considering legislation that would impose tight restrictions on common cold medicines that contain pseudoephedrine, an essential ingredient in making methamphetamine. Although the bills vary in detail, most would classify pseudoephedrine as a controlled substance and would allow sales of products containing it, like Sudafed, only in pharmacies, not in grocery or convenience stores. Customers would have to purchase the medicine from a pharmacist, show photo identification and sign a logbook.
abstract: Faced with growing crisis of methamphetamine addiction and toxic spills from homemade labs, 20 states consider legislation to impose tight restrictions on common cold medicines containing pseudoephedrine, used in making methamphetamine, which has spread from rural West to become top priority for law enforcement in Midwest and Southeast; one motivation for passing laws is concern that makers of methamphetamine may flock to states without restrictions; photos (M)

headline.main: Fighting an Illegal Drug Through Its Legal Source
